text: PREFACE
label: HH3

text: Data responsibility in humanitarian action is the safe, ethical and eﬀective management
label: BODY

text: of personal and non-personal data for operational response. It is a critical issue for the
label: BODY

text: humanitarian system to address and the stakes are high.
label: BODY

text: The OCHA Data Responsibility Guidelines (‘the Guidelines’) oﬀer a set of principles,
label: BODY

text: processes and tools that support data responsibility in OCHA’s work.1
label: BODY

text: The core audience for the Guidelines is OCHA staﬀ involved in managing data across OCHA’s
label: BODY

text: core functions of coordination, advocacy, policy, humanitarian financing and information
label: BODY

text: management, with a primary focus on the field.
label: BODY

text: The Guidelines are informed by a series of gap analysis studies, research and field testing
label: BODY

text: conducted by OCHA over the past several years.2 This includes extensive piloting of a
label: BODY

text: working draf3 of the Guidelines by OCHA oﬀices in ten diﬀerent response contexts in 2019
label: BODY

text: and 2020, with support from the OCHA Centre for Humanitarian Data (‘the Centre’). These
label: BODY

text: pilots informed the revision of the Guidelines for finalization and endorsement in 2021.
label: BODY

text: The Guidelines reflect the latest global guidance and policy instructions within the United
label: BODY

text: Nations (UN) Secretariat and the broader humanitarian system, including:
label: BODY

text: The Secretary-General’s Roadmap for Digital Cooperation4
label: BODY

text: The Secretary-General’s Data Strategy5
label: BODY

text: The Inter-Agency Standing Committee Operational Guidance on Data Responsibility6
label: BODY

text: The Guidelines also reflect forthcoming administrative issuances of the organization related
label: BODY

text: to data protection and privacy. See Annex E for a list of the references that informed the
label: BODY

text: development of the Guidelines and Annex F for a selection of additional resources related to
label: BODY

text: data responsibility in humanitarian action.
label: BODY

text: The Guidelines will be revised every two years.
label: BODY

text: 1     As an office within the United Nations Secretariat, OCHA is subject to applicable policies and directives of the Secretariat.
label: BODY

text: For the purposes of the OCHA Data Responsibility Guidelines, the term Office is used to refer to OCHA. However, references to
label: BODY

text: principles and actions for data responsibility within and across 'humanitarian organization(s)' apply to OCHA as an office of the
label: BODY

text: UN Secretariat.
label: BODY

text: 2    This includes: (a) research conducted in 2016 with the NYU Governance Lab (GovLab) and Leiden University to understand the
label: BODY

text: policy and privacy landscape, and to understand related best practices of partner organizations; (b) a survey conducted by the
label: BODY

text: Centre for Humanitarian Data in March 2018 amongst OCHA staff working with information and/or data; and (c) field research
label: BODY

text: conducted in 2018 with the Centre and OCHA offices to better understand how sensitive data is shared and used by OCHA staff
label: BODY

text: and humanitarian partners in conflict environments.
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: STRUCTURE OF THE GUIDELINES
label: HH3

text: The Guidelines contain five sections and a series of supporting Annexes.
label: BODY

text: Section 1: Introduction oﬀers an overview of key concepts related to data responsibility
label: H4

text: in humanitarian action, explains the role of OCHA in humanitarian data management and
label: BODY

text: clarifies the scope of the Guidelines.
label: BODY

text: Section 2: Principles for Data Responsibility in Humanitarian Action introduces the
label: H4

text: system-wide principles meant to inform the implementation of the Guidelines.
label: BODY

text: Section 3: Data Responsibility in Practice provides practical guidance on how OCHA
label: H4

text: should support actions for data responsibility at the system-wide level, cluster/sector
label: BODY

text: level, and organizational level (e.g. in OCHA oﬀices and in OCHA’s own data management
label: BODY

text: activities).
label: BODY

text: Section 4: Accountability outlines the key roles and responsibilities for ensuring the
label: H4

text: adoption of the Guidelines and explains how these relate to the governance and oversight
label: BODY

text: functions established by forthcoming administrative issuances for the United Nations
label: BODY

text: Secretariat related to data protection and privacy.
label: BODY

text: Section 5: Services to Support Adoption of the Guidelines provides an overview of the
label: H4

text: services available to OCHA staﬀ implementing the Guidelines. These services are oﬀered by
label: BODY

text: the OCHA Centre for Humanitarian Data and are available upon request.
label: BODY

text: Annex A - Definitions provides definitions of key terms used in the Guidelines.
label: BODY

text: Annex B - Principles for Data Responsibility in Humanitarian Action provides a detailed
label: BODY

text: description of the Principles.
label: BODY

text: Annex C - Data Responsibility in OCHA’s Data Management presents a set of steps that
label: BODY

text: OCHA staﬀ should take to uphold data responsibility in a given data management activity.
label: BODY

text: Annex D - Templates for Data Responsibility brings together the diﬀerent templates
label: BODY

text: referenced throughout the Guidelines. Editable versions of each template are available via
label: BODY

text: links included in this Annex.
label: BODY

text: Annex E - Foundations for Data Responsibility at OCHA presents an overview of existing
label: H4

text: instruments that directly or indirectly guide OCHA’s data management.
label: BODY

text: Annex F - Additional Resources oﬀers a set of references related to data responsibility in
label: H4

text: the sector.

text: 1.  INTRODUCTION
label: HH1

text: OCHA Centre for Humanitarian Data
label: BODY

text: October 2021
label: BODY

text: DATA RESPONSIBILITY IN HUMANITARIAN ACTION
label: HH3

text: Data is a critical component of humanitarian response. The management of data relating
label: BODY

text: to crisis contexts, aﬀected people and humanitarian operations allows the humanitarian
label: BODY

text: community to respond more eﬀectively and eﬀiciently. However, as organizations manage
label: BODY

text: increasingly large volumes of data, they also face more complex challenges and risks.
label: BODY

text: Irresponsible data management in humanitarian responses can place already vulnerable
label: BODY

text: people and communities at greater risk of harm or exploitation, e.g. by exposing their
label: BODY

text: location or identifying a key vulnerability. This is of particular concern when humanitarian
label: BODY

text: actors handle sensitive data8 — data that is likely to lead to harm when exposed.
label: BODY

text: Both personal and non-personal data can be sensitive in humanitarian action. While there is
label: BODY

text: a common understanding in the sector regarding the sensitivity of personal data,
label: BODY

text: determining the sensitivity of non-personal data is more complex. For example, locations of
label: BODY

text: medical facilities in conflict settings can expose patients and staﬀ to risk, whereas this data
label: BODY

text: is typically less sensitive in natural disaster response settings. The Guidelines support OCHA
label: BODY

text: staﬀ in determining the sensitivity of data and taking actions to ensure responsible data
label: BODY

text: management.
label: BODY

text: In recent years we have seen the development of principles, policies and strategies for
label: BODY

text: data responsibility in humanitarian action. These include system-wide guidance, such
label: BODY

text: as the Inter-Agency Standing Committee Operational Guidance on Data Responsibility in
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian Action, as well as global strategies and policies to guide data management
label: BODY

text: within the UN system, such as the Secretary-General’s Roadmap for Digital Cooperation and
label: BODY

text: forthcoming administrative issuances for the organization related to data protection and
label: BODY

text: privacy. Despite considerable progress, gaps remain between global frameworks and their
label: BODY

text: practical application in field operations.
label: BODY

text: The OCHA Data Responsibility Guidelines (‘the Guidelines’) are designed to help bridge
label: BODY

text: these gaps by supporting OCHA staﬀ to apply global frameworks for data responsibility in
label: BODY

text: their day-to-day work.
label: BODY

text: DEFINITIONS
label: H4

text: Data responsibility is the safe, ethical and eﬀective management of personal and
label: BODY

text: non-personal data for operational response, in accordance with established
label: BODY

text: frameworks for personal data protection.
label: BODY

text: Safe | Data management activities ensure the security of data at all times,
label: BODY

text: respect and uphold human rights and other legal obligations, and do not cause
label: BODY

text: harm.
label: BODY

text: Ethical | Data management activities are aligned with the established
label: BODY

text: frameworks and standards for humanitarian ethics9 and data ethics.
label: BODY

text: Eﬀective | Data management activities achieve the purpose(s) for which they
label: BODY

text: were carried out.
label: BODY

text: 1. INTRODUCTION
label: H4

text: 8   See the Information Sharing Protocol template for more information on how to develop a data and information sensitivity
label: BODY

text: classification.
label: BODY

text: 9   Humanitarian ethics has developed as a principle-based ethics grounded in the principles of humanity, impartiality, neutrality
label: BODY

text: and independence that guide the provision of humanitarian assistance and protection. These principles and related rules are
label: BODY

text: enshrined in various codes of conduct now widely recognized as the basis for ethical humanitarian practice, including: The
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian Charter and Minimum Standards in Humanitarian Response, including the Core  Standards and Protection
label: BODY

text: Principles, the Core Humanitarian Standard on Quality and Accountability, and the Code of Conduct for the International Red
label: BODY

text: Cross and Red Crescent Movement and Non-Governmental Organizations (NGOs) in Disaster Relief. For additional guidance
label: BODY

text: on humanitarian data ethics see The Centre for Humanitarian Data, Guidance Note: Humanitarian Data Ethics (2019).
label: BODY

text: OCHA Centre for Humanitarian Data
label: BODY

text: October 2021
label: BODY

text: Data responsibility requires the implementation of principled actions at all levels of a
label: BODY

text: humanitarian response. These include for example actions to ensure data protection
label: BODY

text: and data security, as well as strategies to mitigate risks while maximizing benefits in
label: BODY

text: all steps of operational data management. While data responsibility is linked to data
label: BODY

text: protection and data security, these terms are used diﬀerently.
label: BODY

text: Data protection refers to the systematic application of a set of institutional, technical
label: BODY

text: and physical safeguards that preserve the right to privacy with respect to the
label: BODY

text: processing of personal data.
label: BODY

text: Data security is applicable to both personal and non-personal data and refers to
label: BODY

text: technical and organizational measures that aim to preserve the confidentiality,
label: BODY

text: availability, and integrity of data.
label: BODY

text: Operational data management is the design of data management activities and
label: BODY

text: subsequent collection or receipt, storage, processing, analysis, sharing, use, and
label: BODY

text: retention and destruction of data and information by humanitarian actors. Such
label: BODY

text: activities occur as part of humanitarian action throughout the planning and response
label: BODY

text: cycle across clusters/sectors and include, but are not limited to, situational analysis,
label: BODY

text: needs assessments, population data management, registration and enrollment, case
label: BODY

text: management, communicating with aﬀected populations, protection monitoring, and
label: BODY

text: response monitoring and evaluation.
label: BODY

text: Personal data is any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural
label: BODY

text: person (‘data subject’). An identifiable natural person is one who can be identified,
label: BODY

text: directly or indirectly, in particular by reference to an identifier such as a name, an
label: BODY

text: identification number, location data, an online identifier or to one or more factors
label: BODY

text: specific to the physical, physiological, genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social
label: BODY

text: identity of that natural person.
label: BODY

text: Non-personal data is any information which does not relate to a data subject.
label: BODY

text: Non-personal data can be categorized in terms of origin, namely: data that has never
label: BODY

text: related to a data subject, such as data about the context in which a response is taking
label: BODY

text: place and data about humanitarian response actors and their activities; or data that
label: BODY

text: was initially personal data but later made anonymous, such as data about the people
label: BODY

text: aﬀected by the humanitarian situation and their needs, the threats and vulnerabilities
label: BODY

text: they face, and their capacities. Non-personal data includes Demographically
label: BODY

text: Identifiable Information (DII) i.e., data that enables the identification of groups of
label: BODY

text: individuals by demographically defining factors, such as ethnicity, gender, age,
label: BODY

text: occupation, religion, or location.
label: BODY

text: Sensitive Data is classified as such based on the likelihood and severity of potential
label: BODY

text: harm that may materialize as a result of its exposure in a particular context. Both
label: BODY

text: personal and non-personal data can be sensitive. Many organizations have specific
label: BODY

text: classification systems regarding what constitutes sensitive data in order to facilitate
label: BODY

text: data management practices.
label: BODY

text: A full list of definitions is available in Annex A.
label: BODY

text: 1. INTRODUCTION
label: H4

text: OCHA’S ROLE IN HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: BODY

text: MANAGEMENT
label: HH3

text: OCHA plays an important and unique role in humanitarian data management across its
label: BODY

text: core functions of advocacy, coordination, financing, information management, and policy.
label: BODY

text: Whereas other humanitarian organizations process data primarily for their own use, OCHA’s
label: BODY

text: data management is mainly focused on aggregation and analysis for the wider humanitarian
label: BODY

text: community.
label: BODY

text: In most responses, UN agencies, funds and programmes, and non-governmental
label: BODY

text: organization (NGO) partners collect cluster/sector-specific data, such as data on shelter
label: BODY

text: requirements or food consumption, to inform their own response activities. OCHA brings
label: BODY

text: together data from these diﬀerent partners to create a common operational picture of a
label: BODY

text: humanitarian situation. This service helps avoid duplication and supports decision-making
label: BODY

text: by operational and policy leaders in the field and at headquarters.
label: BODY

text: OCHA also plays a critical role in coordinating data management activities across a diverse
label: BODY

text: group of stakeholders. With more actors engaging in crisis response, the hub and spoke
label: BODY

text: model of coordination has shifed to a network model. In this model, OCHA continues
label: BODY

text: to aggregate data for situational awareness but also takes on the added role of network
label: BODY

text: enabler. OCHA’s data role in a network is to connect partners to one another through the
label: BODY

text: provision of services such as common standards and cloud-based infrastructure for storing
label: BODY

text: and transferring data responsibly. In the age of digital data, OCHA’s network enabler role
label: BODY

text: must take into account the risk of hosting or acting as a passthrough for sensitive data from
label: BODY

text: humanitarian partners and third-parties. The Guidelines are designed to support this role.
label: BODY

text: SCOPE OF THE GUIDELINES
label: HH3

text: The Guidelines apply to all operational data managed directly by OCHA, managed on OCHA’s
label: BODY

text: behalf, or managed by humanitarian actors within activities coordinated by OCHA in
label: BODY

text: diﬀerent responses. This includes the following types of data:
label: BODY

text: Data about the context in which a response is taking place (e.g., legal frameworks,
label: BODY

text: political, social and economic conditions, infrastructure, etc.) and relevant dynamics
label: BODY

text: in the area of focus (e.g., security incidents, protection risks, drivers and underlying
label: BODY

text: causes/factors of the situation or crisis).
label: BODY

text: Data about the people aﬀected by the situation and their needs, the threats and
label: BODY

text: vulnerabilities they face, and their capacities (e.g., needs assessment data, population
label: BODY

text: figures, mobility data).
label: BODY

text: Data about the humanitarian response (e.g. 3W data, access data, community
label: BODY

text: perception data and data on humanitarian funding).
label: BODY

text: Common operational data management activities for OCHA include situational analysis,
label: BODY

text: needs assessments, 3W/4W, communicating with aﬀected populations, access monitoring,
label: BODY

text: and response monitoring and evaluation. OCHA’s management of corporate data, such as
label: BODY

text: human resources and financial data, is regulated by existing UN Secretariat rules and is
label: BODY

text: outside the scope of the Guidelines.
label: BODY

text: The Guidelines also address how OCHA should support the implementation of the IASC
label: BODY

text: Operational Guidance on Data Responsibility10 at the system-wide, cluster/sector and OCHA
label: BODY

text: oﬀice (organization) level.
label: BODY

text: The core audience for the Guidelines is OCHA staﬀ involved in managing data across OCHA’s
label: BODY

text: core functions, with a primary focus on the field.
label: BODY

text: OCHA DATA RESPONSIBILITY GUIDELINES
label: HH1

text: 2.  PRINCIPLES FOR DATA
label: HH1

text: RESPONSIBILITY IN
label: HH1

text: HUMANITARIAN ACTION
label: HH1

text: OCHA Centre for Humanitarian Data
label: BODY

text: October 2021
label: BODY

text: The following Principles for Data Responsibility in Humanitarian Action (‘the Principles’)
label: BODY

text: are designed to inform safe, ethical and eﬀective operational data management in
label: BODY

text: humanitarian action. They were developed and endorsed as part of the IASC Operational
label: BODY

text: Guidance on Data Responsibility. The Principles should serve as a normative guide to OCHA
label: BODY

text: staﬀ and partners in implementing actions for data responsibility outlined in the Guidelines.
label: BODY

text: Implementation of these Principles is without prejudice to the privileges and immunities of
label: BODY

text: the UN. They are presented in alphabetical order; no hierarchy is intended.
label: BODY

text: These Principles are based on a review of existing principles for data management across
label: BODY

text: the humanitarian and development sectors.11 They are designed to reinforce humanitarians'
label: BODY

text: overarching commitment to Do No Harm while maximizing the benefits of data.12 The
label: BODY

text: Principles also reaﬀirm the centrality of aﬀected people and their rights and well-being in
label: BODY

text: humanitarian action.
label: BODY

text: The management of personal data should be informed by the principle on Personal Data
label: BODY

text: Protection,13 while the management of non-personal data should be informed by the other
label: BODY

text: principles.
label: BODY

text: Wherever these Principles conflict with one another in their interpretation or application,
label: BODY

text: they should be balanced against each other based on the particular dynamics of the
label: BODY

text: response. In the event that the Principles conflict with either internal policies or applicable
label: BODY

text: legal obligations, the latter take precedent.

text: The system-wide level refers to the highest-level coordination structures in a given
label: BODY

text: response, e.g. the Humanitarian Country Team (HCT) and the Inter-Cluster/Inter-Sector
label: BODY

text: Coordination Group (ICCG/ISCG). As the convener of the ICCG/ISCG and various technical
label: BODY

text: working groups (e.g. the Information Management Working Group [IMWG], the Access
label: BODY

text: Working Group [AWG], the Assessment & Analysis Working Group [AAWG], etc.), OCHA has
label: BODY

text: an important role to play in supporting actions for data responsibility at the system-wide
label: BODY

text: level. There are five actions that should be prioritized by OCHA staﬀ at the system-wide
label: BODY

text: level.

text: RESPONSIBILITY IN
label: H4

text: Purpose:
label: BODY

text: A system-wide data responsibility diagnostic helps identify common opportunities and
label: BODY

text: challenges for responsible data management, informs the prioritization of actions for data
label: BODY

text: responsibility, and provides the HCT with a holistic understanding of data responsibility in
label: BODY

text: the response.
label: BODY

text: OCHA’s Role:
label: BODY

text: OCHA is responsible for initiating and facilitating the system-wide data responsibility
label: BODY

text: diagnostic and presenting it to the HCT for review once finalized.
label: BODY

text: Recommended Approach:
label: BODY

text: ☐  Prepare a draf of the diagnostic based on information available using the IASC OG Data
label: BODY

text: Responsibility Diagnostic Template. This will likely require inputs from both the
label: BODY

text: Coordination and Information Management (IM) teams in the oﬀice.
label: BODY

text: ☐  Circulate the draf to ICCG/ISCG and IMWG members for inputs.
label: BODY

text: ☐  Consolidate inputs and finalize the draf diagnostic for collective review and validation
label: BODY

text: during a joint meeting of the ICCG/ISCG, the IMWG and other thematic or technical
label: BODY

text: working groups as relevant, e.g. the AWG and AAWG.
label: BODY

text: ☐  Share the final diagnostic with the HCT and oﬀer to provide a briefing on the key findings
label: BODY

text: and related recommendations for data responsibility in the response.
label: BODY

text: ☐  Ideally, share the diagnostic jointly with the data ecosystem map (see below).
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Purpose:
label: BODY

text: A system-wide data ecosystem map provides a summary of major data management
label: BODY

text: activities undertaken in the response. It helps identify data gaps and possible duplication,
label: BODY

text: supports complementarity and convergence, facilitates collaboration, and
label: BODY

text: enables prioritization and strategic decision-making on responsible data management.
label: BODY

text: OCHA’s Role:
label: BODY

text: OCHA is responsible for supporting the relevant coordination mechanism(s) in completing
label: BODY

text: a system-wide data ecosystem map. Upon completion, OCHA should present the ecosystem
label: BODY

text: map to the HCT for reference. OCHA should also support periodic updates/revisions to the
label: BODY

text: ecosystem map as the response evolves.
label: BODY

text: Recommended Approach:
label: BODY

text: ☐  Prepare an initial draf of the ecosystem map based on information available using the
label: BODY

text: IASC OG Data Responsibility Diagnostic Template. This should be led by the IM team
label: BODY

text: with input and feedback from the Coordination team.
label: BODY

text: ☐  Circulate the draf data ecosystem map to IMWG members for inputs.
label: BODY

text: ☐  Consolidate inputs and finalize the draf data ecosystem map for collective review and
label: BODY

text: validation during a joint meeting of the ICCG/ISCG, the IMWG and other thematic or
label: BODY

text: technical working groups as relevant, e.g. the AWG and AAWG.
label: BODY

text: ☐  Share the validated ecosystem map with the HCT for reference. As the response evolves,
label: BODY

text: facilitate periodic updates to the ecosystem map as necessary.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Purpose:
label: BODY

text: A system-wide Information Sharing Protocol (ISP) serves as the primary document of
label: BODY

text: reference governing data and information sharing in a response. It includes a context-specific
label: BODY

text: Data and Information Sensitivity Classification outlining the sensitivity and related
label: BODY

text: disclosure protocol for key data types.
label: BODY

text: OCHA’s Role:
label: BODY

text: OCHA is responsible for supporting the ICCG/ISCG and the IMWG in jointly drafing a system-
label: BODY

text: wide ISP for the response.
label: BODY

text: Recommended Approach:
label: BODY

text: ☐  Introduce the concept of developing a system-wide ISP in the relevant coordination
label: BODY

text: forum(s) and agree on an approach and timeline for the process with members. Circulate
label: BODY

text: the draf to ICCG/ISCG and IMWG members for inputs.
label: BODY

text: ☐  Develop an initial draf using the IASC OG Information Sharing Protocol template and
label: BODY

text: circulate with the ICCG/ISCG, the IMWG and other thematic or technical working groups
label: BODY

text: as relevant, e.g. the AWG and AAWG.
label: BODY

text: ☐  Present the ISP to the HCT for review and endorsement once it has been reviewed by the
label: BODY

text: ICCG/ISCG.
label: BODY

text: ☐  All stakeholders involved in data management should be made aware of the ISP and their
label: BODY

text: respective obligations. Depending on the response, OCHA should make the endorsed ISP
label: BODY

text: publicly available (e.g. on ReliefWeb, HRInfo or another response-specific site).

text: Purpose:
label: BODY

text: Tracking and communicating about data incidents fosters learning, supports coordinated
label: BODY

text: approaches to data incident management and helps reduce the risk of incidents occurring.
label: BODY

text: OCHA’s Role:
label: BODY

text: OCHA is responsible for establishing and maintaining a registry of data incidents and
label: BODY

text: providing periodic reports to the HCT.
label: BODY

text: Recommended Approach:
label: BODY

text: ☐  Create a registry that captures key details about the nature, severity, and resolution of
label: BODY

text: diﬀerent incidents. Where appropriate, this may be linked with other system-wide
label: BODY

text: incident monitoring processes and tools, e.g. security and access monitoring systems.
label: BODY

text: Limit access to the registry to prevent unnecessary disclosure of information about
label: BODY

text: incidents.
label: BODY

text: ☐  Introduce the registry to the ICCG/ISCG and the IMWG and ensure that all relevant
label: BODY

text: stakeholders are aware of the process for providing inputs, including thematic or
label: BODY

text: technical working groups as relevant, e.g. the AWG and AAWG.
label: BODY

text: ☐  Encourage inputs by the clusters/sectors on behalf of their members. Individual
label: BODY

text: organizations may also provide inputs based on their own incident management tracking
label: BODY

text: where these inputs are not already covered by contributions from the relevant cluster/
label: BODY

text: sector.
label: BODY

text: ☐  Prepare periodic reports summarizing the nature, severity and resolution tactics that
label: BODY

text: stakeholders are using. When reporting, uphold confidentiality and do not share sensitive
label: BODY

text: data.

text: OCHA’S ROLE IN CLUSTER/SECTOR LEVEL
label: BODY

text: ACTIONS FOR DATA RESPONSIBILITY
label: HH3

text: Supporting data responsibility at the cluster/sector level will complement actions articulated
label: BODY

text: at the system-wide and organization levels. Cluster/Sector Lead and Co-Lead Agencies are
label: BODY

text: responsible for ensuring the actions for data responsibility are undertaken within the scope
label: BODY

text: of a given cluster/sector response, in-line with the IASC Operational Guidance on Data
label: BODY

text: Responsibility in Humanitarian Action. While the actions at this level are primarily designed
label: BODY

text: for national-level clusters/sectors, regional clusters (covering multiple countries) and sub-
label: BODY

text: national clusters may also implement these actions in certain responses.
label: BODY

text: OCHA has no direct role in completing actions at this level but should raise awareness
label: BODY

text: of the IASC-recommended actions for data responsibility at the cluster/sector level. OCHA
label: BODY

text: can support cluster/sector Lead and Co-Lead Agencies through the provision of technical
label: BODY

text: advisory support and liaising with relevant coordination structures as needed. This
label: BODY

text: includes considering the cluster/sector level actions for data responsibility when providing
label: BODY

text: information management support to clusters/sectors.
label: BODY

text: OCHA may also advise on the development of cluster/sector specific ISPs and other actions
label: BODY

text: at this level. OCHA should monitor the adoption and implementation of actions for data
label: BODY

text: responsibility at this level and promote alignment with system-wide level actions wherever
label: BODY

text: possible.

text: DATA RESPONSIBILITY WITHIN OCHA OFFICES
label: HH3

text: Upholding data responsibility at the organization level in a given response setting is critical
label: BODY

text: to the success of the actions for data responsibility at the system-wide and cluster/sector
label: BODY

text: levels. Given the focus of this level in the IASC Operational Guidance on Data Responsibility
label: BODY

text: in Humanitarian Action, the recommended actions for data responsibility are meant for
label: BODY

text: OCHA oﬀices.17 Some actions at this level, such as the development of a Standard Operating
label: BODY

text: Procedure for data incident management, will also be relevant to OCHA headquarters
label: BODY

text: sections in their operational data management.
label: BODY

text: There are seven actions in particular that should be prioritized by OCHA staﬀ at the oﬀice
label: BODY

text: level.
label: BODY

text: 17  Data sharing between OCHA offices and/or with headquarters sections should be informed by the Guidelines and also
label: BODY

text: follow the forthcoming administrative issuances on data protection and privacy for the UN Secretariat.
label: BODY

text: Purpose:
label: BODY

text: A data responsibility diagnostic provides an overview of existing data responsibility
label: BODY

text: measures within the OCHA oﬀice and supports prioritization of additional actions for data
label: BODY

text: responsibility in the response. Conducting a diagnostic helps OCHA gain an understanding
label: BODY

text: of the policy and governance, tools and infrastructure, and competency and capacity related
label: BODY

text: to data management in a response. In turn, this understanding helps prioritize subsequent
label: BODY

text: actions for data responsibility.
label: BODY

text: Recommended Approach:
label: BODY

text: ☐  The data responsibility diagnostic should be conducted jointly by a Humanitarian Aﬀairs
label: BODY

text: Oﬀicer (HAO) and Information Management Oﬀicer (IMO).
label: BODY

text: ☐  Use the OCHA data responsibility diagnostic template to conduct a diagnostic at this level.
label: BODY

text: ☐  Update the diagnostic on an annual basis or when circumstances and/or OCHA’s own
label: BODY

text: data management policies and practices change.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: OCHA Data Responsibility Diagnostic Template

text: 18  There are a variety of data cycles and processes used in documentation across OCHA’s different functions. The Guidelines
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Purpose:
label: BODY

text: A data asset registry provides an overview of the operational data managed by an OCHA
label: BODY

text: oﬀice promotes responsible data management within the oﬀice, and informs the cluster/
label: BODY

text: sector and system-wide data ecosystem maps.
label: BODY

text: Recommended Approach:
label: BODY

text: ☐  The data asset registry should be developed and maintained by an IMO. All staﬀ involved
label: BODY

text: in data management should be aware of the registry and know how to update it.
label: BODY

text: ☐  The data asset registry should at a minimum include the name of each dataset managed
label: BODY

text: by the oﬀice, the data source, a brief description, the method for collection or receipt, the
label: BODY

text: storage location, accessibility of the dataset, the sensitivity classification and a timeline
label: BODY

text: for retention and destruction.
label: BODY

text: ☐  Data sharing should also be recorded, either in the registry or in a separate data sharing
label: BODY

text: log. Information on data sharing should include, at a minimum, the recipient, sharing
label: BODY

text: method and date of sharing.
label: BODY

text: ☐  Note that data with low or no sensitivity should be retained and remain publicly available
label: BODY

text: by default.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Purpose:
label: BODY

text: Including data responsibility considerations in the design, implementation, monitoring and
label: BODY

text: evaluation of data management activities helps minimize risks and maximize benefits. For
label: BODY

text: OCHA, common operational data management activities include but are not limited to
label: BODY

text: situational analysis, coordinated needs assessments, 3W/4W, communicating with aﬀected
label: BODY

text: populations, access monitoring, and response monitoring and evaluation (including through
label: BODY

text: third parties). These activities typically consist of the following eight steps: Planning,
label: BODY

text: Collecting, Receiving and Storing, Assuring Quality, Sharing, Analyzing, Presenting, Retaining
label: BODY

text: and Destroying, and Evaluating.
label: BODY

text: Recommended Approach:
label: BODY

text: ☐  When designing a data management activity, responsible staﬀ should follow the tips along
label: BODY

text: the eight steps presented in the cycle on page 29 and outlined in Annex C.
label: BODY

text: ☐  These tips and related outputs help staﬀ identify and mitigate risks, select appropriate
label: BODY

text: technical tools, use and share data in safe, ethical, and eﬀective ways, and adhere to
label: BODY

text: relevant guidance and protocols throughout a data management activity.
label: BODY

text: ☐  Contact the Centre for guidance on how to adapt these tips to suit the response
label: BODY

text: environment and the data management activity.

text: Purpose:
label: BODY

text: A Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) for data incident management helps reduce the risk
label: BODY

text: of incidents occurring and supports the development of a knowledge base.
label: BODY

text: Recommended Approach:
label: BODY

text: ☐  The SOP should be developed jointly by an HAO and IMO and be confirmed by the Head
label: BODY

text: of Oﬀice.
label: BODY

text: ☐  The SOP should include a process for notification, classification, treatment, and closure
label: BODY

text: of the incident. It should also specify appropriate channels for rectification and redress
label: BODY

text: for individuals impacted by data incidents as determined by the forthcoming
label: BODY

text: administrative issuances on data protection and privacy for the UN Secretariat.
label: BODY

text: ☐  Establish a data incident registry is used to capture key details about the nature, severity
label: BODY

text: and resolution of each incident.
label: BODY

text: ☐  OCHA oﬀices should share their experience in managing and mitigating data incidents
label: BODY

text: with other actors, i.e., at the cluster/sector and system-wide levels to foster more
label: BODY

text: coordinated approaches to incident management.

text: 4.  ACCOUNTABILITY
label: HH1

text: OCHA Centre for Humanitarian Data
label: BODY

text: October 2021
label: BODY

text: All OCHA staﬀ and supporting personnel (e.g. contractors, stand-by partners, and
label: BODY

text: secondments) who are authorized to manage data and related resources across OCHA
label: BODY

text: should follow the Guidelines. Although eﬀective adoption of the Guidelines requires action
label: BODY

text: from all OCHA staﬀ, accountability for adherence to the Guidelines rests with senior
label: BODY

text: managers at headquarters and oﬀice level.
label: BODY

text: The Chief of the Information Management Branch and Lead for the Information
label: BODY

text: Management Function is accountable for the adoption of the Guidelines across OCHA.
label: BODY

text: Every year, the Chief of the Information Management Branch will submit a report to
label: BODY

text: the OCHA Data Steward21 on progress in the adoption of the Guidelines as well as any data
label: BODY

text: incidents that have been reported.
label: BODY

text: The OCHA Centre for Humanitarian Data will track and support the adoption of the
label: BODY

text: Guidelines and support the Chief of the Information Management Branch in reporting on
label: BODY

text: progress as outlined above. The Centre will liaise with the Data Protection Focal Point(s)
label: BODY

text: as necessary to complete these tasks. The Centre will also provide regular updates to the
label: BODY

text: global Data Responsibility Working Group22 on OCHA’s progress and lessons learned in
label: BODY

text: implementing the Guidelines.
label: BODY

text: At the global level, all Functional Leads, and Branch or Section Chiefs whose teams
label: BODY

text: manage data are responsible for ensuring adoption of the Guidelines.
label: BODY

text: At the field-level, Heads of Oﬀice are responsible for ensuring adherence within their oﬀice.
label: BODY

text: Unit Heads are responsible for ensuring the appropriate application of the Guidelines in
label: BODY

text: OCHA’s day-to-day data management work.
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian Aﬀairs Oﬀicers and Information Management Oﬀicers are responsible for
label: BODY

text: supporting implementation of the Guidelines in their respective areas of focus.
label: BODY

text: The table below summarizes key responsibilities of diﬀerent groups/units in supporting
label: BODY

text: adoption of the Guidelines.
label: BODY

text: 21  The forthcoming administrative issuances for the organization related to data protection and privacy establish a set of Data
label: BODY

text: Protection Functions for different UN entities. These include a Data Steward (typically the head of entity) and Data
label: BODY

text: Protection Focal Point(s).
label: BODY

text: 22 The Data Responsibility Working Group (DRWG) is a global coordination body working to advance data responsibility
label: BODY

text: across the humanitarian system. It brings together a diverse group of stakeholders including United Nations (UN) entities,
label: BODY

text: other International Organizations (IOs), Non-Governmental Organizations (NGOs), and other stakeholders engaged in the
label: BODY

text: coordination and implementation of humanitarian action. The DRWG began as an Inter-Agency Standing Committee (IASC)
label: BODY

text: Sub-Group in 2020 and transitioned into a system-wide working group in early 2021. The primary aim of the DRWG is to
label: BODY

text: coordinate, support, and monitor collective action on data responsibility, primarily through the lens of the IASC Operational
label: BODY

text: Guidance on Data Responsibility in Humanitarian Action. Learn more about the DRWG here: https://reliefweb.int/topics/
label: BODY

text: 5.  SERVICES TO SUPPORT
label: HH1

text: ADOPTION OF THE
label: HH1

text: GUIDELINES
label: HH1

text: OCHA Centre for Humanitarian Data
label: BODY

text: October 2021
label: BODY

text: The Centre is committed to supporting oﬀices and sections across OCHA in adopting the
label: BODY

text: Guidelines. The Centre oﬀers the following services upon request.
label: BODY

text: Introductory briefing
label: BODY

text: The Centre will provide introductory webinars to oﬀices or sections upon request. This
label: BODY

text: service focuses on supporting a broad understanding of the Guidelines and answering
label: BODY

text: general questions on how staﬀ can begin implementation in their context.
label: BODY

text: Diagnostic and assessment exercise
label: BODY

text: Many OCHA oﬀices already have a number of the key actions and outputs for data
label: BODY

text: responsibility in place (see Section 3 of the Guidelines). Conducting a diagnostic and
label: BODY

text: assessment of the level of data responsibility in a given oﬀice can help colleagues
label: BODY

text: determine what actions to prioritize in their eﬀorts to adopt and uphold the Guidelines.
label: BODY

text: The Centre is available to conduct or accompany OCHA teams in running this exercise.
label: BODY

text: Ad-hoc advisory services
label: BODY

text: Oﬀices or sections can contact the Centre with specific questions regarding the
label: BODY

text: interpretation or application of the Guidelines. The Centre will log questions and related
label: BODY

text: guidance so that staﬀ can learn from the experience of other oﬀices.
label: BODY

text: Support missions
label: BODY

text: For contexts in which more in-depth support is required, the Centre oﬀers support
label: BODY

text: missions geared towards adapting and adopting the Guidelines, and to facilitate
label: BODY

text: conversations and workshops with OCHA staﬀ and partners on issues related to data
label: BODY

text: responsibility. The missions can be used to develop context-specific protocols for
label: BODY

text: responsible data management.
label: BODY

text: Tools and templates
label: BODY

text: The Centre will continue to develop tools and templates to facilitate the application of
label: BODY

text: the Guidelines to specific activities.
label: BODY

text: Training
label: BODY

text: The Centre has a range of training material on data responsibility skills for OCHA staﬀ
label: BODY

text: and partners. It also oﬀers targeted training support upon request.
label: BODY

text: Development of thematic guidance on data responsibility
label: BODY

text: The Centre will work with diﬀerent teams within OCHA to develop more specific
label: BODY

text: guidance23 on adoption of data responsibility in diﬀerent thematic areas.
label: BODY

text: DEFINITIONS
label: HH3

text: Aggregate data:  Accumulated data acquired by combining individual-level data. It refers
label: BODY

text: to data that is (1) collected from multiple sources and/or on multiple measures, variables,
label: BODY

text: or individuals and (2) compiled into data summaries or summary reports, typically for the
label: BODY

text: purposes of public reporting or statistical analysis.24
label: BODY

text: Consent: Consent is any freely given, specific and informed indication of an agreement by
label: BODY

text: the data subject to the processing of their personal data.25
label: BODY

text: Data: Re-interpretable representation of information in a formalized manner suitable for
label: BODY

text: communication, interpretation, or processing.26
label: BODY

text: Data asset: Data assets are a body of data or information, defined and managed as a single
label: BODY

text: unit so it can be understood, shared, protected and exploited eﬀiciently.27
label: BODY

text: Data asset registry: A data asset registry provides a summary of the key datasets being
label: H4

text: generated and managed by diﬀerent actors in a context.28
label: BODY

text: Data breach: The loss, destruction, alteration, acquisition, or disclosure of information
label: BODY

text: caused by accidental or intentional, unlawful or otherwise unauthorized purposes , which
label: BODY

text: compromise the confidentiality, integrity and/or availability of information.
label: BODY

text: Data cleaning: The process of detecting and correcting (or removing) corrupt or inaccurate
label: BODY

text: records from a record set, table, or database and refers to identifying incomplete, incorrect,
label: BODY

text: inaccurate or irrelevant parts of the data and then replacing, modifying, or deleting the
label: BODY

text: dirty or coarse data.
label: BODY

text: Data consumer: A person or organization that uses data to make decisions, take actions, or
label: BODY

text: increase awareness.
label: BODY

text: Data ecosystem map: A data ecosystem map provides a summary of major data
label: H4

text: management activities, including the scale, scope, and types of data being processed,
label: BODY

text: stakeholders involved, data flows between diﬀerent actors, and processes and platforms in
label: BODY

text: use.29
label: BODY

text: Data impact assessment: A data impact assessment is a generic term to refer to a variety
label: BODY

text: of tools that are used to determine the positive and negative consequences of a data
label: BODY

text: management activity. These include commonly used – and sometimes legally required –
label: BODY

text: tools such as Data Protection Impact Assessments and Privacy Impact Assessments.30
label: BODY

text: Data incidents: Events involving data management, such as the loss, destruction,
label: BODY

text: alteration, acquisition, or disclosure of data and information, caused by accidental or
label: BODY

text: intentional, unlawful or otherwise unauthorized purposes that have caused harm or have
label: BODY

text: the potential to cause harm.31
label: BODY

text: Data management: The data management cycle consists of the following steps: planning,
label: BODY

text: collecting and receiving, storing, cleaning, transfer, analysis, communicating and
label: BODY

text: disseminating, feedback and evaluation, and retention and destruction.

text: Data minimization: The objective of ensuring that only the minimum amount of data is
label: BODY

text: processed to achieve the objective and purposes for which the data were collected.32
label: BODY

text: Data processing: Any operation or set of operations which is performed on data or on
label: BODY

text: sets of data, whether or not by automated means, such as collecting, registering, storing,
label: BODY

text: adapting or altering, cleaning, filing, retrieving, using, disseminating, transferring and
label: BODY

text: retaining or destroying.
label: BODY

text: Data protection: The systematic application of a set of institutional, technical and physical
label: BODY

text: safeguards that preserve the right to privacy with respect to the processing of personal
label: BODY

text: data.33
label: BODY

text: Data Protection Impact Assessment: A tool and process for assessing the protection
label: BODY

text: impacts on data subjects in processing their personal data and for identifying remedial
label: BODY

text: actions as necessary in order to avoid or minimize such impacts.34
label: BODY

text: Data provider: A person or organization that shares data directly or on behalf of another
label: BODY

text: entity.
label: BODY

text: Data quality: A set of characteristics that make the data fit for the purpose for which it
label: BODY

text: is processed. Data quality includes components such as accuracy, relevance, suﬀiciency,
label: BODY

text: integrity, completeness, usability, validity, coherence, punctuality, accessibility,
label: BODY

text: comparability, and timeliness.
label: BODY

text: Data responsibility: A set of principles, processes and tools that support the safe, ethical
label: BODY

text: and eﬀective management of data in humanitarian response.
label: BODY

text: Data security: A set of physical, technological and procedural measures that safeguard the
label: BODY

text: confidentiality, integrity and availability of data and prevent its accidental or intentional,
label: BODY

text: unlawful or otherwise unauthorized loss, destruction, alteration, acquisition, or disclosure.35
label: BODY

text: Data sensitivity: Classification of data based on the likelihood and severity of potential
label: BODY

text: harm that may materialize as a result of its exposure in a particular context.36
label: BODY

text: Data sharing agreement: Agreement that establishes the terms and conditions that govern
label: BODY

text: the sharing of personal data or sensitive non-personal data. It is primarily used for data
label: BODY

text: sharing between two parties and typically established at the country level.37
label: BODY

text: Data source: The original collector of the data concerned.
label: BODY

text: Data subject: A natural person (i.e. an individual) whose personal data is subject to
label: BODY

text: processing, and who can be identified, either directly or indirectly, by reference to this
label: BODY

text: data and reasonably likely measures. The nomination as a data subject is linked to a set of
label: BODY

text: specific data subject rights to which this natural person is entitled with regards to his/ her
label: BODY

text: personal data, even when this data is gathered, collected or otherwise processed by others).
label: BODY

text: Data transfer: The act of transferring data or making it accessible to a partner using any
label: BODY

text: means, such as in hard copy, electronic means or the internet.
label: BODY

text: Harm: Negative implications of a data processing initiative on the rights of a data subject,
label: BODY

text: or a group of data subjects, including but not limited to physical and psychological harm,
label: BODY

text: discrimination and denial of access to services.
label: BODY

text: Information management: Gathering, sharing and using data and information,
label: BODY

text: underpinning coordination, decision-making and advocacy.
label: BODY

text: Information product: Product derived from raw data that is organized in a way that
label: BODY

text: conveys intended information to users (e.g., infographics, charts, maps, situation reports,
label: BODY

text: etc.).
label: BODY

text: Microdata: Observation data on the characteristics of statistical units of a population,
label: BODY

text: such as individuals, households, or establishments, gathered through exercises such as
label: BODY

text: household surveys, needs assessment or monitoring activities.38
label: BODY

text: Non-personal data: Any information which does not relate to a data subject. Non-personal
label: BODY

text: data can be categorized in terms of origin, namely: data that has never related to a data
label: BODY

text: subject, such as data about the context in which a response is taking place and data about
label: BODY

text: humanitarian response actors and their activities; or data that was initially personal data
label: BODY

text: but later made anonymous, such as data about the people aﬀected by the humanitarian
label: BODY

text: situation and their needs, the threats and vulnerabilities they face, and their capacities.
label: BODY

text: Non-personal data includes Demographically Identifiable Information (DII) i.e., data that
label: BODY

text: enables the identification of groups of individuals by demographically defining factors, such
label: BODY

text: as ethnicity, gender, age, occupation, religion, or location.39
label: BODY

text: Operational data management: The design of data management activities and subsequent
label: BODY

text: collection or receipt, storage, processing, analysis, sharing, use, and retention and
label: BODY

text: destruction of data and information by humanitarian actors. Such activities occur as part
label: BODY

text: of humanitarian action throughout the planning and response cycle across clusters/sectors
label: BODY

text: and include, but are not limited to, situational analysis, needs assessments, population data
label: BODY

text: management, registration and enrollment, case management, communicating with aﬀected
label: BODY

text: populations, protection monitoring, and response monitoring and evaluation.40
label: BODY

text: Personal data: Any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person (‘data
label: BODY

text: subject’).An identifiable natural person is one who can be identified, directly or indirectly,
label: BODY

text: in particular by reference to an identifier such as a name, an identification number, location
label: BODY

text: data, an online identifier or to one or more factors specific to the physical, physiological,
label: BODY

text: genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social identity of that natural person.
label: BODY

text: Primary data: Data that has been generated by the researcher himself/herself, surveys,
label: BODY

text: interviews, experiments, specially designed for understanding and solving the research
label: BODY

text: problem at hand.41
label: BODY

text: Privacy: No one shall be subjected to arbitrary or unlawful interference with his privacy,
label: BODY

text: family, home or correspondence, nor to unlawful attacks on his honor and reputation.
label: BODY

text: Everyone has the right to the protection of the law against such interference or attacks.42
label: BODY

text: Re-identification: A process by which de-identified (anonymized) data becomes re-
label: BODY

text: identifiable again and thus can be traced back or linked to an individual(s) or group(s) of
label: BODY

text: individuals through reasonably available means at the time of data re-identification.

text: PRINCIPLES FOR DATA RESPONSIBILITY IN
label: HH3

text: HUMANITARIAN ACTIONS47
label: BODY

text: Accountability
label: BODY

text: In accordance with relevant applicable rules, humanitarian organizations have an
label: BODY

text: obligation to account and accept responsibility for their data management activities.
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian organizations are accountable to people aﬀected by crisis, to internal
label: BODY

text: governance structures, to national and international humanitarian partners, and, if
label: BODY

text: applicable, to national governments and regulatory bodies. To achieve their accountability
label: BODY

text: commitments, humanitarian organizations should put in place all measures required to
label: BODY

text: uphold and monitor adherence to these Principles. This includes establishing adequate
label: BODY

text: policies and mechanisms and ensuring the availability of suﬀicient competencies and
label: BODY

text: capacities, including but not limited to personnel, resource and infrastructure capacity.48
label: BODY

text: Confidentiality
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian organizations should implement appropriate organizational safeguards and
label: BODY

text: procedures to keep sensitive data confidential at all times. Measures should be in line with
label: BODY

text: general confidentiality standards as well as standards specific to the humanitarian sector49
label: BODY

text: and applicable organizational policies and legal requirements, while taking into account
label: BODY

text: the context and associated risks.
label: BODY

text: Coordination and Collaboration
label: BODY

text: Coordinated and collaborative data management entails the meaningful inclusion of
label: BODY

text: humanitarian partners, national and local authorities, people aﬀected by crisis, and
label: BODY

text: other stakeholders in data management activities, all where appropriate and without
label: BODY

text: compromising the humanitarian principles50 or these Principles. Coordination and
label: BODY

text: collaboration should also aim to ensure that appropriate connections are established
label: BODY

text: between humanitarian operational data management activities and longer-term
label: BODY

text: development-oriented data processes and data investments. Local and national capacity
label: BODY

text: should be strengthened wherever possible, and not be undermined.
label: BODY

text: Data Security
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian organizations should implement appropriate organizational and technical
label: BODY

text: safeguards, procedures and systems to prevent, mitigate, report and respond to security
label: BODY

text: breaches. These measures should be suﬀicient to protect against external breaches as well
label: BODY

text: as unauthorized or inappropriate internal access or manipulation, accidental disclosure,
label: BODY

text: damage, alteration, loss, and other risks related to data management.51 Measures should
label: BODY

text: be adjusted based on the sensitivity of the data managed and updated as data security best
label: BODY

text: practice develops, both for digital data and analogue data.
label: BODY

text: ANNEX B
label: H4

label: BODY

text: Defined Purpose, Necessity and Proportionality
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian data management and its related activities should have a clearly defined
label: BODY

text: purpose. The design of processes and systems for data management should contribute
label: BODY

text: to improved humanitarian outcomes, be consistent with relevant mandates and relevant
label: BODY

text: rights and freedoms, and carefully balance those where needed.52 In line with the concept of
label: BODY

text: data minimization, the management of data in humanitarian response should be relevant,
label: BODY

text: limited and proportionate – in terms of required investment as well as identified risk – to the
label: BODY

text: specified purpose(s).
label: BODY

text: Fairness and Legitimacy
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian organizations should manage data in a fair and legitimate manner, in
label: BODY

text: accordance with their mandates, the context of the response, governing instruments,
label: BODY

text: and global norms and standards, including the humanitarian principles. Legitimate
label: BODY

text: grounds for data management include, for example: the best interests of people aﬀected
label: BODY

text: by crisis, consistent with the organization’s mandate; public interest in furtherance of the
label: BODY

text: organization’s mandate; the vital interests of communities and individuals not able to make
label: BODY

text: a determination about data management themselves; and any other legitimate ground
label: BODY

text: specifically identified by the organization’s regulatory framework or applicable laws.
label: BODY

text: Human Rights-Based Approach
label: BODY

text: Data management should be designed and implemented in ways that respect, protect and
label: BODY

text: promote the fulfilment of human rights, including the fundamental freedoms and principles
label: BODY

text: of equality and non-discrimination as defined in human rights frameworks, as well as
label: BODY

text: the more specific right to privacy and other data-related rights, and data-specific rights
label: BODY

text: promulgated in applicable data protection legislation and other applicable regulation.53
label: BODY

text: People-Centered and Inclusive
label: BODY

text: Aﬀected populations should be aﬀorded an opportunity to be included, represented, and
label: BODY

text: empowered to exercise agency throughout data management whenever the operational
label: BODY

text: context permits. Special eﬀorts should be made to support the participation and
label: BODY

text: engagement of people who are not well represented and may be marginalized in the data
label: BODY

text: management activity at hand (e.g., due to age, gender and other diversity factors such as
label: BODY

text: disability, ethnicity, religion, sexual orientation or other characteristics), or are otherwise
label: BODY

text: ‘invisible’, consistent with commitments to leave no one behind. A people-centered and
label: BODY

text: inclusive approach is particularly important in the development of context-specific norms
label: BODY

text: and standards for data management.
label: BODY

text: Personal Data Protection
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian organizations have an obligation to adhere to (i) applicable national and
label: BODY

text: regional data protection laws,54 or (ii) if they enjoy privileges and immunities such that
label: BODY

text: national and regional laws do not apply to them, to their own data protection policies.55
label: BODY

text: These laws and policies contain the list of legitimate bases for the processing of personal
label: BODY

text: data, including but not limited to consent.56 When designing data management systems,
label: BODY

text: humanitarian organizations should meet the standards of privacy and data protection by
label: BODY

text: design and by default. Humanitarian organizations should take personal data protection
label: BODY

text: into consideration when developing open data frameworks. In line with their commitment
label: BODY

text: to inclusivity and respect for human rights, they should ensure the rights of data subjects to
label: BODY

text: be informed about the processing of their personal data, and to be able to access, correct,
label: BODY

text: delete, or object to the processing of their personal data.
label: BODY

text: 52This includes that data management must be relevant, limited and adequate to the intended purpose of data management,
label: BODY

text: which for non-personal data in a sensitive context must be in line with forthcoming administrative issuances for the
label: BODY

text: organization related to data protection and privacy.
label: BODY

text: 53 As part of the United Nations Secretariat, OCHA enjoys privileges and immunities which entail that national and regional
label: BODY

text: legislation on the handling of data do not apply.
label: BODY

text: 54 As part of the United Nations Secretariat, OCHA enjoys privileges and immunities which entail that national and regional
label: BODY

text: legislation on the handling of data do not apply.
label: BODY

text: 55 OCHA must always manage personal data in accordance with applicable guidance, including forthcoming administrative
label: BODY

text: issuances for the organization related to data protection and privacy and the Personal Data Protection and Privacy Principles,
label: BODY

text: which should serve as a foundational framework for the processing of personal data by UN entities.
label: BODY

text: 56 For more information on processing of personal data and the use of ‘consent’ as a legitimate basis in humanitarian response,
label: BODY

text: see the ICRC Handbook on Data Protection in Humanitarian Action (2nd edition, 2020).
label: BODY

text: ANNEX B - PRINCIPLES
label: BODY

text: FOR DATA RESPONSIBILITY
label: H4

text: IN HUMANITARIAN ACTIONS
label: H4

text: OCHA Centre for Humanitarian Data
label: BODY

text: October 2021
label: BODY

text: Quality
label: BODY

text: Data quality should be maintained such that users and key stakeholders are able to trust
label: BODY

text: operational data management and its resulting products. Data quality entails that data is
label: BODY

text: relevant, accurate, timely, complete, up-to-date and interpretable, in line with the intended
label: BODY

text: use and as appropriate within the given context. Where feasible and appropriate, and
label: BODY

text: without compromising these Principles, organizations should strive to collect and analyze
label: BODY

text: data by age, sex and disability disaggregation, as well as by other diversity characteristics as
label: BODY

text: relevant to the defined purpose(s) of an activity.
label: BODY

text: Retention and Destruction
label: BODY

text: Sensitive data should only be retained for as long as it is necessary to the specified purpose
label: BODY

text: for which it is being managed or as required by applicable law or donor audit regulations.
label: BODY

text: When its retention is required, safe and secure storage should be ensured to safeguard
label: BODY

text: sensitive data from being misused or irresponsibly exposed. All other data may be retained
label: BODY

text: indefinitely, provided that its level of sensitivity is reassessed at appropriate moments,
label: BODY

text: that access rights can be established, and – for anonymized or aggregate data – that a
label: BODY

text: re-identification assessment is conducted. Regardless of the sensitivity level, a retention
label: BODY

text: schema should indicate when data should be destroyed and how to do so in a way that
label: BODY

text: renders data retrieval impossible. Specific durations for retention should be defined where
label: BODY

text: possible and, where this is not the case, specific periods for review of necessity should be
label: BODY

text: set.
label: BODY

text: Transparency
label: BODY

text: Data management in humanitarian response should be carried out in ways that oﬀer
label: BODY

text: meaningful transparency toward stakeholders, notably aﬀected populations. This should
label: BODY

text: include provision of information about the data management activity and its outputs, as
label: BODY

text: well as data sharing in ways that promote genuine understanding of the data management
label: BODY

text: activity, its purpose, intended use and sharing, as well as any associated limitations and
label: BODY

text: risks.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: 4. SHARING
label: BODY

text: This involves sharing data
label: BODY

text: privately with partners or
label: BODY

text: making it available publicly for
label: BODY

text: open access.
label: BODY

text: TIPS
label: BODY

text: ☐  Ensure clear documentation of methods used.
label: BODY

text: ☐  Prevent exposure of sensitive data during analysis or visualization.
label: BODY

text: ☐  Take extra precautions when using advanced analytical methods.
label: BODY

text: OUTPUTS
label: BODY

text: ☐  Charts, graphs or maps displaying information, accompanied by
label: BODY

text: appropriate documentation.
label: BODY

text: 5. ANALYZING
label: BODY

text: This focuses on the extraction
label: BODY

text: of information as required for
label: BODY

text: the development of information
label: BODY

text: products.
label: BODY

text: TIPS
label: BODY

text: ☐  Include context and data sources in published products.
label: BODY

text: ☐  Ensure appropriate approval before release and select an appropriate
label: BODY

text: license.
label: BODY

text: OUTPUTS
label: BODY

text: ☐  Responsibly published information products.
label: BODY

text: 6. PRESENTING
label: BODY

text: This involves incorporating
label: BODY

text: insights from the data into
label: BODY

text: internal or public information
label: BODY

text: products and websites.
label: BODY

text: TIPS
label: BODY

text: ☐  Assess the potential future value of data.
label: BODY

text: ☐  Balance the risk and utility of data.
label: BODY

text: ☐  Select the right means for long-term storage.
label: BODY

text: ☐  Regularly reassess the sensitivity level of the data retained.
label: BODY

text: ☐  Ensure eﬀective destruction of data.
label: BODY

text: OUTPUTS
label: BODY

text: ☐  Securely retained datasets.
label: BODY

text: ☐  Eﬀectively destroyed datasets, with clear documentation of this step
label: BODY

text: and the datasets concerned.
label: BODY

text: 7. RETAINING AND DESTROYING
label: BODY

text: This entails keeping data
label: BODY

text: available for future use, or
label: BODY

text: ensuring the removal of data in
label: BODY

text: a way that renders retrieval
label: BODY

text: impossible.
label: BODY

text: TIPS
label: BODY

text: ☐  Include data responsibility considerations in any evaluation exercise
label: BODY

text: conducted for the activity.
label: BODY

text: ☐  Communicate the use of data with stakeholders.
label: BODY

text: ☐  Record any data incidents that occurred throughout the activity.
label: BODY

text: OUTPUTS
label: BODY

text: ☐  Finalized data management activity with documentation of any data
label: BODY

text: incidents.
label: BODY

text: 8. EVALUATING
label: BODY

text: This entails internal review of
label: BODY

text: the data management activity
label: BODY

text: or joint review with partners as
label: BODY

text: appropriate.
label: BODY
